item.title: Bayesian Logistic Regression
item.dc:creator: Erdem K.
item.description:
Bayesian Logistic Regression¶

I am first going to explore concepts in logistic regression. Then I'm going to add a bayesian twist to this ML algorithm and apply it to a couple of familiar problems. Logistic regression takes its name from a logistic equation being applied as a thresholding function, in this case $$z=\frac{1}{(1+exp^{-y})}$$ to the familiar regression line $$y = \alpha + \beta X$$.

Contrary to what one might think at first hearing, this is an algorithm suitable for a classification problem; not a regression problem.

In [17]:
# IMPORTS
import numpy as np
from scipy.special import expit as logistic
import matplotlib.pyplot as pl
import seaborn as sb
import pandas as pd
import pymc3 as pm
% matplotlib inline

Note that the logistic equation is available in scipy as expit, which I rename as logistic for clarity

In [10]:
x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 100)
y = logistic(x)
pl.plot(x,y)
Out[10]:
[<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x7fb1d54836a0>]

I start first with a simple classification problem where the outcome has to be one of two possible classes labeled 0 and 1. Because of the binary outcome, and remembering Kruschke's puppy book, I use the Bernoulli distribution. In reference to the puppy book, the parameterization can be thought of as $$\theta=expit(\alpha + \beta X)$$ and the label $$l \sim Bern\left(\theta\right)$$ where $$l \in [0,1]$$

Let's load the iris dataset

In [11]:
iris = sb.load_dataset("iris")
In [12]:
iris.head(2)
Out[12]:
sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species
0 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa
1 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa

The dataset has 4 features, and a corresponding species label. That is the label we will predict.

In [13]:
iris.species.unique()
Out[13]:
array(['setosa', 'versicolor', 'virginica'], dtype=object)

There are 3 possible species so I'll have to do some magic to adapt this dataset to a binary labeling. But first, I will examine the relationship between features.

In [14]:
sb.pairplot(iris, hue='species')
Out[14]:
<seaborn.axisgrid.PairGrid at 0x7fb1dd08b588>

It looks like it will be easier to separate setosa from the other two. Maybe I can reduce my dataset to setosa and versicolor.

In [23]:
iris.columns
Out[23]:
Index(['sepal_length', 'sepal_width', 'petal_length', 'petal_width',
       'species'],
      dtype='object')
In [24]:
df = iris.query("species == ('setosa', 'versicolor')")
y0 = pd.Categorical(df.species).codes
x0 = df.sepal_length.values
In [ ]:
from sklearn.naive_bayes
In [ ]:
with pm.Model() as model1:
    # setting up my priors:
    alpha = pm.Normal('alpha', mu=0, sd=10)
    beta = pm.Normal('beta', mu=0, sd=10)
    mu = alpha + pm.dot(x0, beta)
